subtitle: Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. This is
going to be a bit freewheeling today
because I don't really have an agenda.
But one thing I do want to say, I've been
thinking about the “In Presence” monologue
that I created and it was released, as I
recall, two days ago about becoming a
cyborg. I realized that I am much
more akin to a cyborg than I appreciated
because I have, in addition to a
pacemaker now, I have hearing aids that I
wear. For the last ten years I've
been using a CPAP machine to sleep with
because I have sleep apneas. So, I've got
now three different items and it just
occurred to me I've got an appointment
tomorrow with a doctor to discuss a
possible knee replacement. So, between the
knee replacement, the CPAP machine, the
hearing aids and the pacemaker, not
to mention I'll probably yet get,
or be due for a hip replacement, maybe
two hip replacements and another knee
replacement before I'm all done. So,
there's no doubt in my mind that our
society is accelerating in the direction
of the interface between humans and
human technology. We are becoming part of
the technology that we are creating and
it's happening at a very rapid pace
right now. Well, when I say rapid you have
to think of it relative to the history
of life on this planet. That's an
interesting thing to think about because
life on the planet began, it is said,
about 4 billion years ago. That's roughly
when the first microbes appeared.
Incidentally, to my understanding, those
microbes were anaerobic, they gave off
oxygen as a poisonous byproduct. In fact,
I understand in the early centuries of
this planet these anaerobic life forms
began choking in their own pollution. All
the oxygen that they were giving off was
becoming deadly for them. As a result
they mutated, in effect they became aerobic,
as we are. We breathe in oxygen, instead
of breathing it out. So, I suppose the
anaerobic life forms were breathing in
carbon dioxide or something like that
and breathing out oxygen. But it's
interesting because they mutated, they
went through a huge transformation as a
result of all the oxygen they had
ended up generating in the atmosphere of
this planet. At least, that's the story,
I'm told. Now, here's another thing to think
about. If life on the planet is 4
billion years old and human life, as I
understand it, modern humans such as
ourselves have been on the planet... they
can find bones of modern humans that go
back maybe 200,000 years. Well,
200,000 years in the 4 billion year
history of life on this planet is
really, really tiny. I think it means it's
like 1/20,000th of the total history
of life on this planet. Of those
200,000 years we have had what we think
of as civilization, why for no more than
20 [20,000 years] I suppose, maybe only a 1/10th of
the time at most that humans were on the
planet. After all, written records go back
only about 5,000 years. What a short
period of time. Think of the enormous
transformation of the planet that has
occurred in the last 5,000 years.
It's happening so rapidly
we don't know where it's leading. In
fact, who can say where it's going to go?
There's nobody who has any answers. Maybe
some great leader will come along and
set a direction for a portion of
humanity for a period of time. But that's
about it. Unless there's some higher
intelligence guiding us, we're on our own.
How's that going to work out? You
know, as I think about the solar system
and the galaxy and I think about the
cosmos, and I love to think about the
cosmos. I go out on the back porch of
this lovely large house that we have now
purchased here in Albuquerque, and I love
to sit out and watch the sky. We're at
about a 6,000 foot altitude so
the sky is pretty clear even though
we're in a metropolitan area. I can see
lots of stars. It's beautiful
late at night. These days you can see
Mars, Saturn and Jupiter, all at the same
time, brilliant in the sky. So, I think a
lot about the cosmos and about the
possibility of life on other planets. I
wonder, for example, am I likely to be
reincarnated on a different planet, what
would that be like? How many other
civilizations are out there?
Civilization is a funny word. I mean what
does it mean to have a civilization? How
intelligent is our civilization when we
seem to be creating global warming and
doing a lot of damage to the planet? Well,
the planet will survive us. We may
destroy ourselves. I wonder, is every
civilization destined to destroy the
planet that gave birth to it? Is that
what civilizations do? Because if you
look at the history of evolution on the
planet you can see many
examples where a certain species will
become so successful that it basically
ends up destroying its environment and
becoming extinct. Any number of species
have already gone extinct. There's no
reason to think that humans will be
exempt from that. But, given our
intelligence, given our visionary
capacities, given our spiritual grounding,
given even our parapsychological
capacities, don't you think it might be
our destiny that we should overcome
these problems that we're facing, these
challenges?
Perhaps we will mutate into an even
more advanced species, but it will still in
some sense be human.
Maybe we're destined to survive the very
problems that we have created. Well, I
think about these things, I do.
Ultimately, I realize I don't have
the answers. I wonder if anybody really
has the answers. I've come to appreciate
that there's so much more we don't know
than we really know. We don't know, for
example, what it was like for humans in
the 190,000 year
history that we had before we developed
civilization. What was it that
triggered civilization, finally, after so
long? Why did that happen?
Were there other civilizations here
before humans? I was reading an article
today that said, “Yeah, there could have
been some other intelligent, let's say
intelligent reptiles, maybe a 100
million years ago who had an advanced
civilization.” And how would we know?
Because over time
whatever artifacts they may have created
could be destroyed. And you think, “Really?
We find fossils that are so much older
than that.” We can look at the ground and
see all the sedimentary layers and
understand so much about geological
history. You'd think if there had been an
earlier civilization we would know about
it. But then, as I say, there's so much we
don't know. What we don't know is like a
million times, a zillion times more than
we do know. We're that ignorant.
We are that ignorant. So, I guess, what's in
all of this for you? What is the lesson
here? What is the lesson here for you?
I can only say that since I'm concluding
on the note of the ignorance of the
human species, how can we be humble in
the face of our ignorance? How can we
realistically appreciate and treat our
own ignorance? I'll leave you with that
thought.
Thank you once again for being with
me.
